last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4362100
If you're in a temperate climate, put all of your plants right up against the window. Understory jungle plants can be placed further back, but not too far - for example, five metres away from a window is really stretching it if you want it to survive longterm. But then it also depends on how large the windows are and what type of glass they're made of, and the colour of your walls and even your furniture also plays a role, and so on. My advice will always be to give your plants as much light as you possibly can, and if after several weeks/months (during the growing season) you still notice them struggling with sunburn, and you're sure you didn't underwater them or let some pest wreak havoc, then you can take the struggling plants a bit further away from the window, but again, not too far. There's already an enormous difference in the amount of light that will reach plants that are right up against the window, and the amount that will reach plants only half a metre away.

>>4362587
Sounds like you're seeing springtails, and what's killing your succulents is not them (they're beneficial), but overwatering caused in part by using a mainly peat-based soil. If you could post some pictures of the dying succulents and the insects, it'd be easier to tell what's going on.

>>4360406
I know what you mean, but these are my lab rats and they're bred in extremely strict conditions to be incredibly resistant to disease. Just wanted to clear up this misunderstanding between laboratory animals and general albino feeders, if people are interested in rescuing. Laboratory rats cost b/w $300-$2000 per rat. In labs they're housed in shoe box sized tanks with only the barred roof for ventilation. It's only cleaned once a week, but even with the immense ammonia buildup these rats never succumb to respiratory illness. Probably the only advantage of having biomedical research grade sprague dawleys. If they experienced any health issues beyond the ones being studied, it would ruin experiments, so it's ensured that these strains are highly resistant to all diseases and cancers. They are born completely mycoplasma free as well. The downsides are that they're extremely skittish, poorly socialized, have poor vision, and have had little to no enrichment for most of their lives (so they're pretty deprived).

threads.com:
I know this is probably very controversial. I'm a brainlet with no idea how genetics actually works.
Some scientists seem to think genetics will heavily influence the breed personality :
https://www.science.org/content/article/dog-breeds-really-do-have-distinct-personalities-and-they-re-rooted-dna
When others say it really doesn't matter that much.
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/dogs-personalities-arent-determined-by-their-breed/
Which one is it really?

last_replies.name: sage
last_replies.com: The "doesn't really matter that much" paper doesn't even say it doesn't matter. Honestly, people who write articles (as someone who's published - human research- but published) should have someone to act as a liaison to help fucking journalists understand research or at least critically appraise it. The second article actually establishes strong heritability for certain traits (including aggressiveness and sociability) but notes there is a fair amount of intra-breed variation. No fucking shit. But that doesn't mean an effect size of a chihaua or pit bull being 25% more likely to bite compared to a labrador retriever isn't a non-negligible effect size. Especially when other social traits (such as training, biddability, etc) are likely to ameliorate others. GSDs are also extremely likely to bite, but they are *much* easier to train compared to Pitbulls or other terrier breeds. The problem happens when even though your Jack Russell is statistically as likely (or more likely) to bite little Tina, you might get a few pucture wounds. When Rudy the Pitbull bites, you get a dead toddler.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4362733
Dogs were originally bred for personality, not appearance, with good results. Looks first breeding largely destroys the work of personality first breeding and is the sole reason breeds have inconsistent temperament. A backyard line bred dog-show type dog may be more aggressive than the real working stock "mongrel". As jobs get more specific dogs get more inbred, naturally, because with things like herding, pointing, and retrieving, you go beyond personality and into disordered wolf instincts.

Humans, too, are bred for personality first, and the result has been crime/violence declining century over century.

Alright this is completely unrelated to the topic on hand, but I’m fucking sick of people using monster hunter terms of deciding what’s a “wyvern”. Why? Because a wyvern isn’t just “a 4 limbed dragon with wings for arms”. I’m sick of know-it-all nerds going WELL AKSHUALLY SMAUG IS A WYVERN IN THE MOVIES BECAUSE HE ONLY GOT 4 LIMBS. Movie Smaug is a dragon, a four-limbed dragon, NOT a wyvern, and here’s why.
A wyvern is a completely unique draconic creature, not the same as dragons. A wyvern always only have 4 limbs, two wings and two legs, but that’s not what makes a wyvern a wyvern. Here’s what constitutes a wyvern:
>a wyvern ALWAYS have 4 limbs of 2 wings and 2 legs, as previously stated.
>a wyvern ALWAYS have a prehensile tail.
>a wyvern is ALWAYS venomous, and the venom is delivered in the form of a stinger at the end of its tail. THIS IS A CRUCIAL FEATURE OF A WYVERN.
>a wyvern’s intelligence never go past that of a beast, unlike dragons which can range from animalistic to sapient.
>a wyvern does NOT have to have a breath attack, which is signature for dragons.
>a wyvern is sometimes depicted with vague avian-like features, such as beaked jaws or sparse feathers between its scales.
TL;DR: stop calling any 4 limbed winged dragons as wyverns, because they’re not.
